title: Useful Git command
content:
[toc]
Update a branch (feature) with different branch (develop) git checkout develop git pull git checkout feature git merge develop # or git rebase develop  The difference between with git rebase is that rebase keep all commits history from your branch, and that is important if your partial commits have a lot of content that can be interesting to keep. This option is obligatory in some teams.
Remove grey submodule git rm --cached <folder_name> git add . git commit -m "<your_message>" git push --all

title: Useful commands for docker
content:
References Top 10 Docker CLI commands you can’t live without
Lists running containers # show all containers docker ps -a # only list ids docker ps -q  Get base image from Docker Hub docker pull  Build docker images from a Dockerfile and a “context” docker build -t container_label .  Run a docker container based on an image Top 10 options for docker run
docker run my_image -it bash   --detach, -d --entrypoint --env, -e or --env-file --ip --name --publish, -p | --publish-all, -P --rm --tty, -t Command use with the option --interactive, -i --volume, -v --workdir, -w  Display the logs of a container docker logs --follow my_container  List the volumes, which are the preferred mechanism for persisting data generated by and used by Docker containers docker volume ls  Removes one or more containers docker rm my_container  Removes one or more images docker rmi my_image  Stops one or more containers docker stop my_container # docker kill my_container  Kill all running containers docker kill $(docker ps -q)  Delete all stopped containers docker rm $(docker ps -a -q)  Delete all images docker rmi $(docker images -q)  Update all images docker images |grep -v REPOSITORY|awk '{print $1}'|xargs -L1 docker pull  Enter a running docker container docker exec -it [container-id] bash  Copy file from docker container to host docker cp <containerId>:/file/path/within/container /host/path/target  List ports defined on a container docker port CONTAINER [Private_port[/protocol]] # Example $ docker port proxy 80/tcp -> 0.0.0.0:80 $ docker port proxy 80 0.0.0.0:80  A vs B Dokerfile EXPOSE vs publish EXPOSE:
When writing your dockerfiles, the instruction EXPOSE tells Docker the running container listens on specific network ports.
EXPOSE <port> [<port>/<protocol>...]  Or within docker run command:
docker run --expose=1234 my_container  Publish ports and map them to the host
There are several flags you can use when using the docker run command to publish a container’s ports outside of the container’s network and map them to the host machine’s ports.
docker run -p 80:80/tcp -p 80:80/udp my_app # To publish all the ports you define in your Dockerfile with EXPOSE and bind them to the host machine, you can use -P flag docker run -P my_app

title: Collections
content:
Don’t do something you’ll lie to yourself later. Live in a matter you can bear to remember accurately.
It is fruitless to wish you had started years ago. In the future you will wish you had started now. Don’t wish. Act.
“Why did this happen to me?” Why not? Events will never conform perfectly to your desires. Move forward.

title: aboutme
content:
About Me and this site My name is Adenosine. And this is my site to record my learning and thinking process.
4 years ago, I was a undergraduate student majored in the Plant Genetics. 2 years ago, I was a Applied Math and Statistics master student. And now, I am a data scientist and developer in Cloud Computing. And I found switching between different area is fantastic experience, and it also give me different perspectives to look at questions.
As a engineer, I always believe “quantity” is the only factor that make difference. When you stack up ideas and work, everything changes. Such as nucleic acid sequence, only needs A,C,G,T, it can generate billions of forms of life. And in the world of computer, 1 and 0 carry enormous information in a light speed.
“How could I make difference?” I asked myself. That’s why I started publish my thinking and works on this site. My goal is update this site once a week at the beginning. When I am more familiar with english writing and get more time, I am going to update it more often.
Adenosine Feb 10th 2019
